body: {"body": " (CNN)Donald Trump said Thursday that Ben Carson's self-described \"pathological temper\" is incurable -- adding that it's like the sickness of a \"child molester.\"  \n\"It's in the book that he's got a pathological temper
description: \" speaking about Carson's autobiography. \"That's a big problem because you don't cure that ... as an example: child molesting. You don't cure these people. You don't cure a child molester. There's no cure for it. Pathological
title: there's no cure for that.\"\nIn his 1990 autobiography
topics: \" Carson attributes violent behavior in his youth to his \"disease
people: \" a \"pathological temper\" that the Republican presidential hopeful said caused him to strike one friend with a rock and attempt to stab another. In subsequent accounts of his violent youth
org: Carson said he once attempted to attack his mother with a hammer. \n\"I'm not bringing up anything that's not in his book
authors: when he says he went after his mother and wanted to hit her in the head with a hammer
orgs: that's pretty bad. When he says he's pathological -- and he says that in the book
article_id: I don't say that -- and again
column15: I'm not saying anything other than pathological is a very serious disease. And he said he's pathological
column16: somebody said he has pathological disease.\"\nRELATED: Trump says most undocumented immigrants don't pay taxes\nCarson has used the story of overcoming his temper as the cornerstone of a remarkable life story
column17: which took him up from poverty in Detroit to Yale
column18: where he began on a track that would make him one of his generation's most respected and accomplished neurosurgeons. \n\"When he said he hit a friend of his in the face with a lock
column24: \" Trump said in the interview. \"And when he said he stabbed somebody with a knife but it hit a belt buckle -- I know all about knives and belt buckles. Belt buckles aren't gonna stop because they can turn
column25: they can twist ... they're not solid especially if somebody's got a couple extra pounds on them.\"\nAsked by Burnett if he were satisfied by Carson's assurances that he left his anger long behind
column27: \" he said. \"You'll have to ask him that question. Look
column28: I hope he's fine because I think it would be a shame. What he's saying is these things happen. It'd be nice if he said none of these things did happen. He's saying these things happen and therefore I have credibility. And what I'm saying is
column29: I'd rather have them if they didn't happen. I don't want somebody who hit somebody in the face with a padlock.\"\n"
column31: "description": "Donald Trump said Thursday that Ben Carson's self-described \"pathological temper\" is incurable -- adding that it's like the sickness of a \"child molester.\""
column32: "title": "Trump likens Carson's 'pathology' to that of a child molester"

body: {"body": " (AP) \u00e2\u0080\u0094 Republican presidential candidates agree that Islamic extremists are running rampant
byline: the Mideast is on fire and Russia
description: China and Iran are flexing their muscles
title: yet they are far from reaching consensus on how much is enough when it comes to spending on defense.\nIt's a political divide that has dogged the GOP since 2010 \u00e2\u0080\u0094 defense hawks versus deficit hawks born in the tea party movement. It also reflects a war-weary nation as conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan drag on with no end in sight and President Barack Obama decides to deploy up to 50 Special Operations forces to Syria.\nThe divisions were on stark display during Tuesday's night debate. In a heated exchange
url: Florida Sen. Marco Rubio called for raising defense spending significantly. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz wants more robust spending
topics: too
people: but he doesn't want to make the deficit larger. Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul's isolationist bent makes him less willing for the U.S. to get involved abroad and he wondered aloud how spending more money on defense qualifies a candidate as a conservative.\n\"Defense spending has fallen dramatically on President Obama's watch
org: and our forces have been reduced and suffered readiness challenges even as threats abroad increase
election_confidence: \" Rubio said. \"Our military therefore needs a serious program of reinvestment and modernization.\"\nHe failed to mention that the cuts to defense spending as well as to domestic spending were largely the result of the 2011 budget pact between Obama and congressional Republicans
authors: who were intent on reducing the nation's deficit.\nPaul
date_written: who has proposed a budget in the past that would have cut spending across the board to curb deficits
orgs: said he wants a strong national defense
article_id: \"but I don't want us to be bankrupt.\"\nCongress just approved spending $607 billion on defense next year
date_access: and the United States is still the world's largest military spender \"at nearly three times the level of second-placed China
column15: \" according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. Russia and Saudi Arabia are third and fourth
column17: the bipartisan National Defense Panel released a report last year that strongly condemned the current state of the U.S. military. It said U.S. military strength has been weakened by deep budget cuts that started with the 2011 budget law. \"Budget cuts have left the military in disrepair
column18: \" the panel's report said. The Budget Control Act has created a \"readiness crisis\" and has caused shortfalls in present and future capabilities.\nThat has prompted U.S. allies to question the United States' resolve on the world stage
column19: the report said. If the budget cuts are not stopped
column20: the U.S. military will become a hollow force
column21: the report said. Several candidates have embraced the panel's findings in their campaign rhetoric
column22:
but few have provided their desired price tag for the Pentagon budget.
What some of the other GOP candidates have said about defense spending:
___
JEB BUSH
In his June speech announcing his presidential campaign
column23: the former Florida governor called the Obama administration \"risk averse\" and said that Obama was leading America into a state of \"military inferiority.\n\"We need to increase defense spending significantly if we are to carry out our global responsibilities today and modernize our armed forces for the future
column24:
" said Bush.
___
BEN CARSON
The retired neurosurgeon told conservative radio talk show host Hugh Hewitt that the U.S. is no longer just cutting fat from the Pentagon budget
column25:
but is "cutting into the muscle and cutting into the bone."
Carson said he thinks the United States needs to be able to respond to at least three areas of the world simultaneously and will be in jeopardy if it can't.
___
LINDSEY GRAHAM
The South Carolina senator is a defense hawk who has repeatedly clashed with deficit hawks.
"Our ballooning national debt poses a serious threat to our national security
column26: but failed attempts to address it by blindly and recklessly slashing military funding are equally dangerous
column27:
" Graham says on his campaign website.
____
DONALD TRUMP
The wealthy businessman said other nations are beating the U.S. economically and militarily.
"We have to make our military bigger
column29: stronger than ever before so that nobody messes with us
column34: \"We can't continue to be the policeman of the world. ... We have a country that's going to hell. We have an infrastructure that's falling apart.\"\n___\nThis story has been corrected to reflect that the budget control act was in 2011."

Scott Olson / Getty Images
Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul on Wednesday continued his attack on Florida Sen. Marco over military spending. 
The two candidates for the Republican presidential nomination clashed at Tuesday's GOP debate over defense spending and the budget in one of the night's more heated exchanges. 
"I went right at Marco Rubio
people: because I frankly don't think he's a conservative
org: \" Paul said of his presidential rival. \"He offered a trillion dollars
authors: for new spending for the new military
date_written: with no explanation about how he was going to pay for it. But then he also offered a trillion dollars of a new entitlement program which will be refundable tax credits.\"\nEarlier in the interview
article_id: \"They all want unlimited funds for the military and they think the military can't have enough.\"\n\"I don't want us to be hallowed out by debt
column15:
saying he understood and felt the nationalism calling for a strong military but the nation couldn't survive mounting debt.

body: {"body": " (CNN)Editor's Note: Watch the interview with Donald Trump on Erin Burnett OutFront at 7 p.m. ET\nDonald Trump said Thursday that undocumented immigrants cost the U.S. economy up to $300 billion annually
byline: and that no more than 10% of the 11 million living in the country pay taxes.\n\"Illegal immigration
description: each year
title: costs us between $200 billion and $300 billion
url:
" Trump told Erin Burnett during an interview for "Erin Burnett OutFront." "I don't know if anybody gives you those numbers. Probably not."
Trump insisted that people living in the U.S. without documentation are avoiding taxation at all levels.
"Do you really believe they pay taxes?" Trump asked Burnett in a clip of the interview that was aired on "The Lead with Jake Tapper."
Burnett pushed back on Trump
topics: noting that undocumented immigrants' incomes are often taxed by state and local governments. \n\"But there's very little
org: \" Trump said. \"There's very little
authors: 10 percent.\"\nBetween 50% and 75% of undocumented immigrants pay some taxes
date_written: according to information in a 2007 report from the Congressional Budget Office.\n"

title: and Lieutenant Governor-elect Jenean Hampton

Ky. (AP)


What Kentucky’s Democratic governor has done to implement ObamaCare may soon be undone by the Republican governor-elect.
Matt Bevin
authors: who defeated Kentucky Attorney General Jack Conway 53 percent to 44 percent Nov. 3
date_written: campaigned on uprooting Gov. Steve Beshear\u2019s ObamaCare exchange and Medicaid expansion.\nWithout support from a divided Kentucky Legislature
orgs: Beshear created a state-run ObamaCare exchange and opted in to ObamaCare\u2019s expansion of Medicaid to working-age adults with no kids and no disabilities.\nPraising Beshear during his 2014 State of the Union speech
article_id: President Obama said the governor was \u201clike a man possessed\u201d when it came to implementing ObamaCare \u2014 regardless of opposition from state legislators.\nUnfortunately for Obama and fans of his unpopular health insurance law
date_access:
Beshear’s unilateral actions leave the state’s two biggest pro-ObamaCare decisions open to reversal from Bevin.

Bevin won the Republican primary after promising to roll back ObamaCare expansion. He aims to shut down Kynect — the state’s ObamaCare exchange — and direct Kentuckians to the federal exchange by the end of 2016.
Click for more from Watchdog.org"
column16: "description": "What Kentucky\u2019s Democratic governor has done to implement ObamaCare may soon be undone by the Republican governor-elect."
column17: "title": "Governor-elect Bevin set to roll back ObamaCare in Kentucky"

body:
{"body": "






 




Too many of the men and women I have met on the campaign trail are disillusioned with a government that they believe no longer works for them. Indeed
byline: 75 percent of Americans now believe that our government is corrupt. They believe that it favors the big
description: the powerful
title: the wealthy
url: and the well-connected\u2014and they are right.\nFor decades
topics: under both Democrat and Republican leadership
people: the government has continued to grow in size
org: in power
election_confidence: and in complexity.\nSpending increased to $3.5 trillion in 2014. Our national debt is over $18 trillion. Since 2001
authors: there have been over 4
date_written: 500 changes to the tax code\u2014an average of more than one per day. There are nearly 1
orgs: 000 rules governing the operation of small businesses
article_id: more than at any point in the last decade.\nAs the government grows more bloated and more complex
column16: and the well-connected\u2014because only they can afford to hire armies of lawyers
column18:
and lobbyists to handle big government. And here's the truth: It can't be fair unless it's simple.

I have spent my whole life challenging the status quo and overhauling bloated bureaucracies. It’s what I did at Hewlett-Packard and it is what I will do when I lead the federal government.

That is the dirty little secret of giant
column19: expensive regulations like ObamaCare or Dodd-Frank. They were written in part by lobbyists for big companies who want the rules to work for them. \nThe passage of ObamaCare is bringing rising premiums for many Americans\u2014and tens of millions of dollars in profits for drug companies. Dodd-Frank has crushed more than 1
column20: 500 of the community banks that provide half the loans to small businesses\u2014while the ten banks too big to fail have simply become five banks too big to fail.\nAs government grows
column21: it also becomes much more difficult to hold people and agencies accountable and to root out this type of corruption. \nIt is how Lois Lerner was able to get away with her illegal
column22: partisan attacks on conservatives. \nIt is how the Department of Veterans Affairs became a stain on our nation\u2019s honor
column23: with hundreds of thousands of veterans dying awaiting health care. \nIt is how Hillary Clinton has been able to repeat her lies about Benghazi.\nBut there is an opportunity here
column24: if our next president is prepared to seize it. \nAll of our wounds are self-inflicted\u2014and all of our problems are fixable. \nIt will take citizenship and it will take leadership
column26: we can fix them.\nThere\u2019s an old saying that if all you have is a hammer
column27: everything looks like a nail. For politicians
column28: regulations and bureaucracy are their hammer. For too long
column29: they have been in the business of managing problems and they have forgotten that leadership is about envisioning solutions.\nWe need a proven
column30: tested leader in the White House\u2014someone who has challenged the status quo and who is not afraid to make enemies. \nShe must be prepared to change the order of things because she hasn\u2019t spent her whole life in the system. \nWe need a president of courage and conviction
column31: who is committed to citizen government and who will engage you to solve our nation\u2019s problems.\nI have spent my whole life challenging the status quo and overhauling bloated bureaucracies. It\u2019s what I did at Hewlett-Packard and it is what I will do when I lead the federal government.\nFirst
column32: we have to move to zero-based budgeting. Every agency must justify every dollar that they spend. We have to roll back the regulations that are crushing the small businesses that create two thirds of the jobs in our country.\nWe must also shrink the size of our bloated bureaucracy. Over the next five years
column33: hundreds of thousands of federal employees are expected to retire. \nI would not replace a single one. At the same time
column34: we must move to a pay-for-performance system and turn the federal government into a meritocracy.\nWe must examine every regulation on the books today. Congress should pass the REINS Act
column35: which will require every major regulation from the White House to be reviewed and voted up or down.\nFinally and most importantly
column36:
we must engage the American people. Technology allows us to do this easily. 
I will use that technology to engage you and put pressure on the political class to actually get something done.
Politicians have gotten us into this mess. It will take a proven leader and citizens to get us out of it. 
It's time to take our government back. 

Carly Fiorina is a candidate for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination. She served as chairman and CEO of Hewlett-Packard from 1999 to 2005.  She has also served on the Defense Business Board
column37:
as the chairman of the CIA's External Advisory Board and on the Advisory Group for Transformational Diplomacy for the Department of State. Follow her on Twitter @CarlyFiorina.


+ FollowFoxNewsOpinion on Facebook

"

body: {"body": "Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz said the November 2016 general election will turn on the question of amnesty for undocumented\u00c2\u00a0immigrants in November
byline: and described himself as\u00c2\u00a0the lone candidate able\u00c2\u00a0to unite various factions of conservative Republicans.\nAt\u00c2\u00a0a press conference after officially registering for the New Hampshire primary
description: Mr. Cruz said that \u00e2\u0080\u009cmillions\u00e2\u0080\u009d of Republicans will stay home in November if they believe the GOP nominee is soft on immigration
title: particularly working-class voters who he says would see amnesty for undocumented immigrants\u00c2\u00a0as a threat to their ability to find well-paying work.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThere is a real socioeconomic divide
url: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Mr. Cruz said. He contrasted himself with \u00e2\u0080\u009celites in Washington\u00e2\u0080\u009d who look to illegal immigrants as a pool of cheap labor
topics: driving down labor prices in the process.\nRunning with a hard line on immigration\u00c2\u00a0will also help to attract Reagan Democrats who would support presumed Democratic Hillary Clinton
people: Mr. Cruz said.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI will stand with the working men and women and that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s how I think we will win the general election.. we run a populist campaign
org: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Mr. Cruz said. \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe run that against the bipartisan corruption of Washington that Hillary Clinton embodies.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nThe Texas senator derided\u00c2\u00a0his\u00c2\u00a0Republican rivals as\u00c2\u00a0\u00e2\u0080\u009ccampaign conservatives
election_confidence: \u00e2\u0080\u009d arguing only he reflects the positions of the party\u2019s\u00c2\u00a0hard right on all issues.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI am the only candidate running who has been a consistent conservative
authors: who has been a fiscal conservative
article_id: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Mr. Cruz said.\nMr. Cruz didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t name those \u201ccampaign conservatives\u201d there
date_access: but on Laura Ingraham\u2019s radio show on Thursday
column15: Mr. Cruz criticized\u00c2\u00a0Mr. Rubio\u2019s past support for a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and for not backing Senate amendments to the legislation that would have boosted enforcement actions.\nMr. Rubio co-sponsored a bipartisan 2013 immigration overhaul bill that would have strengthened border security while also granting an eventual path to citizenship for some undocumented immigrants. The measure passed in the Senate but the Republican-led House never held a vote.\n\u201cHe opposed every single one of them. Every single amendment
column16: \u201d Mr. Cruz said about Mr. Rubio .\u201dMy reaction in all of politics is
column18: \u00e2\u0080\u0099 that you know where someone is based on their actions.\u201d\nSouth Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham registered for the New Hampshire primary earlier\u00c2\u00a0Thursday
column19:
and former Sen. Rick Santorum was also slated to do the same. Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul is set toÂ registerÂ on Friday.
New Hampshire holds its first in the nation primary election onÂ Feb. 9Â next year.

body: {"body": "White supremacists are praising Donald Trump for citing a 1950s U.S. government policy that deported hundreds of thousands of Mexican immigrants."
description:
"description": "“This represents a milestone in the immigration debate.”

Joshua Lott / AFP / Getty Images
White supremacists are praising Donald Trump for citing a 1950s U.S. government policy that deported hundreds of thousands of Mexican immigrants.
After Trump mentioned the policy
title: called \"Operation Wetback
url: \" at Tuesday night's Republican presidential debate
topics: Richard B. Spencer
people: the president of the white nationalist National Policy Institute
org: tweeted
authors: fuck yeah!\" \n\"Mass deportation would be easy and could easily be done humanely
date_written: \" he added in another tweet during the debate.\nA post that ran on the white nationalist site Vdare.com and the white supremacist site Daily Stormer called it a \"milestone in the immigration debate.\"\n\"This represents a milestone in the immigration debate
article_id: Trump demolished the argument that deporting illegals is not feasible. The only question now is whether we have the will to do it.\"\nA photo of President Dwight Eisenhower pointing at the reader ran at the bottom of the post declaring
date_access: \"Ike wants you to help Make America Great Again.\"\nUnder \"Operation Wetback
column16: the government deported hundreds of thousands of Mexicans (the exact total has been called into question) via buses and ships
column17: depositing them in various places in Mexico. The operation has since been widely condemned for violating human rights.\nTrump previously referred to Eisenhower's policy in an interview for CBS' 60 Minutes as an example of how he planned to round up undocumented immigrants in a \"very humane way
column18: a very nice way.\" At the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night
column19: Trump suggested Eisenhower's popularity shows that mass deportation could be done humanely. \n\"Let me just tell you that Dwight Eisenhower. Good president. Great president
column20: \" Trump said at the Fox Business debate. \"People liked him. I liked him. I Like Ike
column22: 'I like Ike.' Moved 1.5 million illegal immigrants out of this country. Moved them just beyond the border
column23: they came back. Moved them again beyond the border
column24: they came back. Didn't like it. Moved 'em waaaay south
column25: they never came back. Dwight Eisenhower. You don't get nicer
column26: you don't get friendlier. They moved 1.5 million people out. We have no choice. We. Have. No. Choice.\"\nJared Taylor
column27: who runs the site American Renaissance (which says that \"one of the most destructive myths of modern times is that people of all races have the same average intelligence\")
column28: wrote in an email to BuzzFeed News that the policy was a \"useful model.\"\n\"If jobs dry up and illegals realize the feds will come for them eventually
column29: they won't wait. They'll choose when and how to leave
column30: \" Taylor said. \n\"Most whites want illegals gone because most illegals are Hispanic
column31: \" Taylor added. \"They wouldn't dare say that
column32: but look at what they do. When the neighborhood or the school turns Mexican
column33: they move. I'm different from other whites only because I say it out loud: I'd rather live in a white society.\"\nTrump's citing of the policy was also well received on StormFront.org
column34: the white nationalist Internet forum site founded by former Ku Klux Klan leader and white supremacist Don Black.\nOn his radio program
column35: Black called Trump \"the alpha male\" on the debate stage
column36: and his co-host Don Advo said he was happy that Trump \"evoked Dwight Eisenhower
column37: \" on immigration. \n\"Trump is holding firm on his anti-immigration policy
column38: \" said Advo\n\"Donald Trump is to be commended. He really is to be supported
column39: \" stated Advo. \"One thing that you can do to support him and support the cause of the pro-white narrative is that if you live in a state where you are not registered as a Republican you need to register as a Republican so you can vote for him in the primary.\"\n\"He is telling the truth about the racial realities of the immigrant invasion
column41: who runs the white nationalist blog Occidental Dissent under the pseudonym \"Hunter Wallace\"
column42: expressed disappointment in Trump for saying he would let deported immigrants back into the country. \n\"I watched the debate and Trump said that he would deport the 11 million
column43:
but he keeps saying he would allow them to come back. That disturbs me. What's the point of deporting all these people if you only plan to let them back into the country?"

LINK: Top Racists And Neo-Nazis Back Donald Trump
"
column44: "title": "White Supremacists Are Thrilled Donald Trump Mentioned \"Operation Wetback\""

description: playing the sensible establishment candidate in a race that has favored conservative\u00a0outsiders
title: on Thursday defended his stances on\u00a0bank bailouts and a pathway to citizenship for illegal\u00a0immigrants.\n\u201cThe idea that we are going to ship 11 million people out of this country and go into neighborhoods and round them up is simply not practical
url: \u201d Mr. Kasich said after speaking to senior citizens here Thursday afternoon. \u201cI just think the practical solution is that if they haven\u2019t violated the law
topics: they have a path to legalization.\u201d\nMr. Kasich has sought to contrast his\u00a0views on immigration with those of hardliners such as Donald Trump and U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz
people: highlighted most recently in Tuesday\u2019s Wall Street Journal/Fox Business debate. Mr. Kasich\u00a0and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush are the only Republicans running who currently support some route to legal status\u00a0for undocumented\u00a0immigrants.\nMr. Trump has pledged to round up millions of illegal immigrants and deport them. Also Thursday
org: \u00a0Mr. Cruz said that \u201cmillions\u201d of Republicans will stay home in November if they believe the GOP nominee is soft on immigration.\nOn Tuesday
election_confidence: Mr. Kasich sparred with Mr. Cruz during the debate over what should have been done about financial institutions that neared collapse in 2008. The Ohio governor Thursday stood by his view that the Obama administration\u2019s bailout was necessary to protect people\u00a0of modest means.\n\u201cThey are the folks who have to be looked out for
authors: \u201d Mr. Kasich said of depositors. \u201cI\u2019m not for bailing out the investors in the banks.\u201d\nMr. Kasich\u2019s strategy has yet to pay off. He was on the bubble for being included in Tuesday\u2019s Republican primetime debate based on his national poll numbers
date_written: and he could be knocked off the main stage by the time of next month\u2019s forum. He\u00a0has focused his campaigning almost exclusively on New Hampshire
orgs: while the polls used so far to determine top-tier candidates haven\u2019t been state specific.\nMr. Kasich said he felt good about his debate performance
article_id: and that it helped highlight a growing divide between candidates who have tangible policies to help the American people as opposed to ones that will increase the U.S. deficit
date_access: endanger entitlement programs or have \u201cnumbers that don\u2019t add up.\u201d\nThose policies won\u2019t stand up during a general election fight
column15: Mr. Kasich said.\n\u201cI want to make sure we have conservative solutions with a conservative candidate who can actually get things done for our country
column16: \u201d Mr. Kasich said.\nSpeaking before a crowd of more than 100 seniors Thursday
column17: Mr. Kasich said he stood by his view that Ohio\u2019s minimum wage increase was helpful to the state\u2019s economy and wouldn\u2019t negatively impact small business owners.\nHe also said that Planned Parenthood should be defunded
column18: a response that several of the seniors loudly booed. The crowd wasn\u2019t of any one party affiliation.\nMore\nFor John Kasich

description: "description": "\nBen Carson isn't only challenging Donald Trump's frontrunner status in the Republican presidential primaries \u2014 he's beating him in book sales
title: too.Trump's new book
topics: will debut on the New York Times hardcover nonfiction bestseller list at #5 \u2014 one spot below Carson's book
people: A More Perfect Union. The yet-to-be-released list was sent to BuzzFeed News by a publishing industry source
org: and will appear in the Nov. 22 edition of the New York Times Book Review.Trump's title does edge out Carson's in the less-closely-followed \"combined print and e-book\" category: On that list
election_confidence: Crippled America is at #4 and A More Perfect Union is at #5. But many industry observers expected Trump's book to dominate the bestseller list.As BuzzFeed News recently reported
authors: the celebrity billionaire's proposal was passed over earlier this year by some publishers
date_written: who were skeptical of his staying power in the 2016 race
orgs: and then came to regret their decision.Carson's performance on the Times list is particularly impressive given that his book has already been out for more than a month: This will be A More Perfect Union's fifth week as a bestseller. By contrast
article_id: Cripple America is benefitting from the surge of publicity and sales that typically accompany a book's first week on the shelves.Carson and Trump \u2014 currently locked in a dead heat for first place in the 2016 primary polls \u2014 are both prolific bestselling authors. Carson became the country's most famous neurosurgeon
date_access: and an icon in the African-American community
column15: thanks largely to his bestselling 1996 memoir Gifted Hands. And Trump has spent much of this year touting his popular 1987 business book The Art of the Deal
column16:
which he calls his second favorite book (behind only the Bible).


"
column17: "title": "Donald Trump's New Book To Debut Behind Ben Carson's On New York Times Bestseller List"
